title: David's Census and Repentance
shortSummary: In 2 Samuel 24, King David orders a census of Israel and Judah, which displeases the LORD and brings judgment upon the nation. After David recognizes his sin, he intercedes for the people, and God provides a way to halt the plague through the building of an altar and offering sacrifices.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David in Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who orders the census, later repents for his sin and builds an altar to stop the plague.

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: Captain of David's army who carries out the census reluctantly and reports the numbers to David.

keyCharacters.name: Gad
keyCharacters.description: David's prophet who delivers God's message of judgment and instructions for repentance.

keyCharacters.name: Araunah
keyCharacters.description: A Jebusite who offers his threshing floor and oxen to David for building an altar to the LORD.

definitions.definition: An official count or survey of a population, often for military or taxation purposes.
A flat area where grain is separated from the chaff, often used as a site for sacrifices in the Old Testament.
A deadly plague or epidemic disease sent as divine judgment.
A sacrificial offering completely consumed by fire, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.

outline.heading: David Orders the Census
outline.description: God's anger leads David to command a census of Israel and Judah, which Joab reluctantly carries out, resulting in a count of 1.3 million valiant men.

outline.heading: David's Repentance and God's Choice of Judgment
outline.description: David realizes his sin and pleads for mercy. God offers David a choice of three punishments, and David chooses to fall into God's hands, trusting His mercy.

outline.heading: The Plague and God's Mercy
outline.description: A devastating pestilence strikes Israel, killing 70,000 men, but God halts the destruction at Jerusalem in response to David's intercession.

outline.heading: Building the Altar and Offering Sacrifice
outline.description: Following Gad's instructions, David purchases Araunah's threshing floor, builds an altar, and offers sacrifices, leading to God's forgiveness and the cessation of the plague.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and confess it promptly to God, trusting in His mercy and forgiveness.
Obedience to God's commands is essential, even when it requires humility and costly sacrifice.
Trust God's sovereign judgment and mercy rather than relying on human strength or numbers.
Offer God your best and do not give Him what costs you nothing, reflecting sincere devotion.

keyVerses.text: And David's heart smote him after that he had numbered the people. And David said unto the LORD, I have sinned greatly in that I have done: and now, I beseech thee, O LORD, take away the iniquity of thy servant; for I have done very foolishly.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights David's repentance and recognition of sin, a model for believers to confess and seek God's forgiveness.

keyVerses.text: And David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let us fall now into the hand of the LORD; for his mercies are great: and let me not fall into the hand of man.
keyVerses.significance: David expresses trust in God's mercy over human judgment, teaching reliance on God's grace in times of trial.

keyVerses.text: And the king said unto Araunah, Nay; but I will surely buy it of thee at a price: neither will I offer burnt offerings unto the LORD my God of that which doth cost me nothing. So David bought the threshingfloor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
keyVerses.significance: David's insistence on paying for the sacrifice teaches the importance of offering God what is costly and sincere.

keyVerses.text: And David built there an altar unto the LORD, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. So the LORD was intreated for the land, and the plague was stayed from Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the power of obedience and sacrifice to bring God's mercy and deliverance.
